Award.AwardTitle: Exploring the Neural Mechanisms of Physics Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, to be conducted by researchers at Florida International University, will extend the research base and theory behind Modeling Instruction (MI), a curriculum intervention for college-level physics. The project is based on the idea that different teaching approaches in physics (MI versus traditional lectures) will lead to different student knowledge, which leads to observable differences in brain structures associated with physics reasoning. The project will also examine gender differences in physics learning. This project will advance the work of the REAL (Research on Education and Learning) program in studying the neural and cognitive basis of STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) learning.

The project will use fMRI (functional magnetic resonance imaging) to study brain activity, focusing on brain regions including the left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, bilateral parahippocampal gyrus, left fusiform gyrus (all associated with fact retrieval), medial and lateral prefrontal cortices and medial and right posterior parietal cortices (all associated with reasoning). Additional neural measures will assess functional brain connectivity, as a measure of neural efficiency of reasoning. The project will also employ behavioral and educational measures of intelligence, anxiety, and physics knowledge, including the FCI (Force Concept Inventory).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Realizing best practices in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) education has never been more important than it is today. Yet innovations in transforming STEM education to promote success and broaden participation have been hampered by a fundamental lack of understanding of how neural changes enable learning. Using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), this project studied brain and behavioral data from 107 students (48 women, 59 men) across University-level physics instruction to characterize underlying neural mechanisms and determine how these support comprehension and proficiency. 

First, this project demonstrated that integrated executive, attentional, visual motion, and default mode brain systems cooperate to achieve physics-related cognition. These observations demonstrate differences in concept formation are paralleled by dissociabilities in the functional organization of students? brain networks. Moreover, these differences link student success with reasoning processes, providing insight into the underpinnings of learning difficulties and how to prevent them. Learning physics is complex, yet a disproportionate instructional focus is often placed on whether students answer questions correctly. Our results indicate the conceptual foundations of wrong answers reveal much more about student?s ability to succeed, can explain functional brain differences during reasoning, and may guide instruction. A focus on accuracy alone over-simplifies the complex processes engaged during physics reasoning. Our results suggest instructors may support learning by leveraging students? existing conceptions as resources to transition existing ideas into stable and accessible associations that help connect what students believe with what they predict.

Second, we observed longitudinal learning-related changes in female and male students across both traditional lecture and active learning class types within a mixed frontoparietal and default mode network (DMN). Increased task-related activity was demonstrated in the frontoparietal network in male students, and in DMN and visual areas in female students. Regions showing significant interactions between pedagogy, sex, and time were revealed during physics retrieval, suggesting male and female students may engage brain areas differently during physics thinking, depending on whether they completed a traditional or active learning physics class. These results suggest that critical differences between female and male students may be mitigated via increased emphasis on visualization and use of diagrams and pictures during reasoning, as well as enhanced incorporation of classroom demonstrations to promote conceptual embodiment and a physical understanding of Newtonian mechanics. 

Third,stronger inter-network brain connectivity was observed during general compared to physics retrieval between the DMN and right central executive networks, and between the left and right central executive networks (CEN). Sex differences revealed enhanced network connectivity between the left CEN and hippocampus in female students compared to their male counterparts during physics retrieval, but no such differences were observed during general retrieval. Intelligence was unrelated to network connectivity and to academic performance. Whole-brain analyses uncovered a sub-network that was more strongly connected during general than physics retrieval. These results indicate a Hebbian-like learning mechanism, such that older (e.g., general) knowledge retrieval relies on a more strongly connected neural network than newer (e.g., physics) retrieval. 

Fourth, we examined the impact of STEM anxiety on student brain networks, including science, math, and spatial anxiety. We found sex differences in STEM-related but not clinical anxiety, with longitudinal increases in science anxiety for both female and male students. Sex-specific impacts of STEM anxiety on brain connectivity emerged, with male students exhibiting separate inter-network brain connections for STEM and clinical anxiety and female students demonstrating no significant within-sex correlations. Anxiety was negatively correlated with academic performance in sex-specific ways at both pre- and post-instruction. Moreover, math anxiety in male students mediated DMN-salience inter-network connectivity and course grade. Thus, we observed that female and male students experience different levels of STEM anxiety and exhibit different neural support for this anxiety, which differentially impacts their academic success. This occurs despite no sex differences in academic performance, providing strong evidence disproving the persistent stereotypes that male students outperform female students in math and science. The gender gap in STEM remains largely unexplained, yet our results suggest that female students maintain performance compared to their male counterparts while responding differently to obstacles and challenges of STEM learning.

Overall, this project has yielded significant advances in understanding the neural systems supporting physics cognition, how these systems change during a semester of learning, how these changes differ between female and male students, and how academic performance and STEM anxiety may play a role. We believe this study deepens and broadens our understanding of student science reasoning and exemplifies the potential of educational neuroscience to provide valuable insight into classroom learning practices that promote student success. This study was performed at Florida International University, which is the fourth largest university in the US and both a Hispanic-Serving and Minority-Serving Institution. FIU is deeply committed to improving STEM education practices and our results thus emphasize learning and academic success achieved by individuals who are under-represented in the STEM disciplines.
